speaker: Sixian You
transcript: Hi everyone. My name is Sishan Yo. Uh, I recently started in electric engineering department at MIT. My background is in optics and microscopy. Uh, so, uh, we are very much troubled by deep tissue imaging because uh, we're we're blessed with this submicro resolution but we can rarely go deeper than millimeter uh depth. So what my lab does, uh, we want to tackle this issue and also a lot of other like imaging speed or contrast issue from three aspects. The first aspect is uh, um multiphoton imaging.

transcript: So what do we do in my lab? We're using um we're using actually clinically and clinical and research tools um to translate light and sound. speaker: Brad Smith
transcript: I mean, I understand that problem in sort of in a clinical circumstance that you see a large piece of tissue and then you go in and then you try to do it almost cellular level microscopy.

speaker: Brad Smith
transcript: What are the challenges, Carolyn?

speaker: Carolyn Bayer
transcript: Well, spatial resolution, right? So we're obviously not in the same domain as far as spatial resolution. So um, and then when you start thinking about how to improve spatial resolution, then sensitivity becomes a problem, you know, as you're imaging smaller and smaller objects.
